bio:treatment.discussion: Oligotrichum falcatum is widely distributed in the Arctic. It is locally common and not infrequently fruiting in northern Alaska and Yukon. In Nunavut, it is known from Axel Heiberg and Melville islands. Similar to O. hercynicum, it is distinguished by the regularly falcate-secund leaves, with abaxial lamellae scarcely developed. Steere noted that in the field, submerged plants have a silvery-green appearance, due to air trapped in the abaxial cells of the costa.

references.reference: Steere, W. C. and Gary L. Smith. 1976. The sporophyte of Oligotrichum falcatum. Bryologist 79: 447–451.
